citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The attending veterinarian was not made aware of the sudden death of 2 llamas and a pig nor was he notified of 2 llamas
with neurological problems. The facility did consult with another veterinarian however, per a facility representative, the
animals died before care could be provided. Furthermore, the attending veterinarian did not know that the facility currently
feeds mainly corn to the pigs and stated that this did not constitute an appropriately complete/balanced diet for them.
When the veterinarian is not given the appropriate authority, the provision of veterinary care may be inadequate or
inappropriate. The licensee must assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision
of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. To be corrected by
December 05, 2025.

The contingency plan available for review at the time of inspection was dated in April 2023, more than 2 years ago. The
plan must be reviewed at least annually to ensure that it continues to adequately address the regulatory requirements and
the facility must maintain documentation of those annual reviews. Correct by ensuring the facility's contingency plan is
reviewed annually and maintaining documentation of the annual reviews. Correct by January 22, 2026.

Two areas were identified in need of repair:
o A missing wooden board at the bottom of the fence between the two pig enclosures created a significant gap spanning
an approximately 5 foot area (between two posts) with exposed sharp metal points throughout. The metal wire at the
bottom of the fence in the area preceding the gap curled up creating sharp points protruding into the enclosure spanning
an approximately 4 foot area.
o The back corner fence of the enclosure containing a zebu and a sheep was leaning significantly. Per a facility
representative, the camel on the other side of the fence, has been leaning on and damaging the fence.
Damaged areas such as these could result in animal injury. The animal housing facilities must be maintained in good
repair to protect the animals from injury and to safely contain the animals. Correct by December 12, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The attending veterinarian was not made aware of the sudden death of 2 llamas and a pig nor was he notified of 2 llamas 
with neurological problems. The facility did consult with another veterinarian however, per a facility representative, the 
animals died before care could be provided. Furthermore, the attending veterinarian did not know that the facility currently 
feeds mainly corn to the pigs and stated that this did not constitute an appropriately complete/balanced diet for them. 
When the veterinarian is not given the appropriate authority, the provision of veterinary care may be inadequate or 
inappropriate. The licensee must assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision 
of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. To be corrected by 
December 05, 2025. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The contingency plan available for review at the time of inspection was dated in April 2023, more than 2 years ago. The 
plan must be reviewed at least annually to ensure that it continues to adequately address the regulatory requirements and 
the facility must maintain documentation of those annual reviews. Correct by ensuring the facility's contingency plan is 
reviewed annually and maintaining documentation of the annual reviews. Correct by January 22, 2026. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Two areas were identified in need of repair: 
o A missing wooden board at the bottom of the fence between the two pig enclosures created a significant gap spanning 
an approximately 5 foot area (between two posts) with exposed sharp metal points throughout. The metal wire at the 
bottom of the fence in the area preceding the gap curled up creating sharp points protruding into the enclosure spanning 
an approximately 4 foot area.  
o The back corner fence of the enclosure containing a zebu and a sheep was leaning significantly. Per a facility 
representative, the camel on the other side of the fence, has been leaning on and damaging the fence.  
Damaged areas such as these could result in animal injury. The animal housing facilities must be maintained in good 
repair to protect the animals from injury and to safely contain the animals. Correct by December 12, 2025.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
